Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Analyzing trait-dependent diversification in lanternfishes (Scopelomorpha; Myctophidae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project represents the first quantitative study of the effects that different forms of a sexually dimorphic bioluminescent trait have on patterns of species diversity in lanternfishes (family Myctophidae), one of the most common and widely distributed deep-sea vertebrate groups. Analysis will be conducted in three stages. First, an evolutionary tree of over 130 lanternfish species will be constructed, using both mitochondrial and nuclear protein-coding DNA sequences. Second, data on the innervation of the bioluminescent trait will be gathered using a combination of traditional and novel imaging techniques to more accurately determine the number and structure of traits. Third, the different traits will be mapped onto the evolutionary tree. Patterns of dimorphism will then be statistically compared with patterns of monomorphism to assess the effect of dimorphic bioluminescent traits on diversification in lanternfishes.

The deep sea is both the largest and least well-known region on Earth, and bioluminescence is one of the most abundant traits across the tree of life. Despite these facts, no studies have yet quantitatively analyzed the effect of differences in bioluminescent structures on patterns of species diversity in deep-sea organisms. Lanternfishes present an ideal model group for enhancing our understanding of evolution in this poorly understood realm.

Context:

Studies in evolutionary biology have, in recent years, focused on developing and employing powerful statistical models to test hypotheses about how quickly, and through what mechanisms, organisms are changing through space and time. Yet although these developments have enabled more precise statements to be made about rates and causes of evolution, the conclusions drawn from such models about global evolutionary processes have been limited to inferences available from accessible terrestrial, freshwater, and near-shore organisms, which live in environments representing less than a quarter of the volume of Earth. Therefore, the general evolutionary patterns and processes inferred from such accessible systems represent a limited and biased sample. To expand understanding of evolution at a truly global scale, this project applied statistical models to organisms from the deep-sea environment, which represents over three-quarters of Earth’s volume.

Intellectual Merit:

Based on statistical analysis of evolutionary rates associated with a light-emitting (bioluminescent) organ, in the context of the largest evolutionary tree ever assembled for a group of deep-sea organisms, this study contradicted untested conventional wisdom about the evolutionary consequences of bioluminescence by providing the first evidence that one such organ is associated with decreased, rather than increased, evolutionary rates in lanternfishes, the world’s most abundant deep-sea vertebrate. This study further showed that features of the lanternfish bioluminescent organ evolved in an irreversible sequence, providing the first evidence that this phenomenon, known in terrestrial organisms, occurs in both the deep sea and in a bioluminescent organ. Furthermore, the specific sequence of evolution within the features of the lanternfish organ agreed with model predictions of a specific type of natural selection hypothesized to be otherwise uncommon based on studies of terrestrial taxa.

Analysis of body shape within the context of the evolutionary tree of two related groups of lanternfishes with diverse body plans showed that these fishes exhibited a significant evolutionary trend toward body elongation, and that light-emitting body organs (photophores) in these fishes—hypothesized to influence speciation—instead strongly tracked the axis of elongation. Furthermore, analysis of correlations among body shape components in these fishes showed that the lowest covariation occurred between the anterior (head) and posterior (tail) regions, thereby providing evidence for an explicit modular structure potentially serving as the constraint through which shape diversity in these fishes is generated. These results provided the first explicit evidence that the positions of photophores are influenced by larger-scale changes in body form that are likely related to environmentally-imposed constraints on movement.
